Some basic economics:   1. Like all costs to the producer, tariffs (import taxes) are passed on to the consumer in the form of higher prices. If Americans buy these higher priced goods, Americans will be paying for the wall.   2. High tariffs are designed to keep foreign goods out of our markets by raising the price of goods. They are called protective tariffs because their purpose is to protect industry at home rather than raise revenues. So Americans may not buy imported products and so monies will not be collected for the wall.  3. If Mexico cannot sell to the US because of high tariffs, then they will not be able to buy from the US, hurting our producers.    4. Tariffs interfere with free markets. Free markets are the basis of capitalism. Worldwide trade cements good foreign relations and promotes peace and prosperity.    5. Fewer workers means lowered economic productivity and fewer people paying Social Security taxes and income taxes.    The wall is NOT an answer to anything."},{"comment_id":"1135518873173382","message":"And women get pregnant by themselves ??????"},{"comment_id":"1137413312974974","message":"Her health is terrible now. Airbnb does NOT collect ANY 'deposits' from our guests in advance at all! And then - to cover up their role as accomplice in this theft... the message thread between ourselves and the thieves - who at one point admit the damages and offer compensation... that message thread gets deleted from Airbnb's site! We, like Mr. Trump, are fiscally conservative, steadfastly pro-life and believers in a small government that fosters freedom for individuals and businesses, so they can grow and become prosperous.   We are deeply concerned about illegal immigration, a major cause of high black unemployment, especially among black youth.   Black Americans across America are beginning to wake up and see clearly the reality of what is happening in black neighborhoods. Democrats have run black communities for the past 60 years and the socialist policies of the Democrats have turned those communities into economic and social wastelands, witness Detroit, Baltimore and South Chicago.   We believe that Mr. Trump has demonstrated that he can push back against the mainstream media, end political correctness and free black communities from the destructive grip of socialist Democrats.   We urge our fellow black Americans to seize control over their own destiny and leverage their vote the way other groups do. The name may change but my symptoms remain the same."},{"comment_id":"10156392542555652","message":"Deborah Vane"},{"comment_id":"10156434885130652","message":"Analy Munoz Flores"},{"comment_id":"10156504442190652","message":"Yes, Matthew, the concept of breaking a complex problem down to it's components is well practiced in the sciences... it works for understanding the components, but rarely for the whole, due to \"\"\"\"emergent properties\"\"\"\". That is characteristics and properties that are only present in the combination of components that cannot exist with the components in isolation. If we use a football team as an analogy, you could examine each player and their specific role, position, capabilities, but you'll never observe the coordinated tactics and strategies without the team. In the case of 'cancer', there are so many variations involved that what happens specifically on a molecular or cellular level in one variant, may be absent in others, even though the interactions manifest similar behaviours at the tissue and systems levels, the underlying mechanisms and pathophysiologies are the likely best candidate for targeting treatments. At present we have limited options (physical removal, chemical or radiation treatment, some immunotherapies) because the mechanisms involved in so many are still in the process of discovery. Whilst it's true that nature provides many starting points for pharmacological developments (many medicines are derived from plants... good example is opioid analgesics, derived from poppies)... their effectiveness is due to specific interactions with cell and tissue receptors. These compounds mimic the properties of intrinsic/endogenous compounds in the body (yes, your body produces opioid like substances in response to pain inducing stimuli). In order to solve the problems of specific diseases of the human body, we need to better understand the various mechanisms and systems on all levels first.  You probably won't believe me when I say that you have my sympathies on the loss of your father. I have also lost several family members to various forms of cancer... so I understand some of the emotions you'd be feeling. I won't do the disservice of saying how you should or shouldn't feel... that's entirely yours.  I will say this much though... research and development involves considerable time, equipment, resources, expertise. None of these things come without a cost and unfortunately the reality is that those costs have to be picked up somewhere. Until we have a utopian government with an economy that doesn't involve money, our reality is that the people involved pay for those services, developments, products, etc. If a corporate entity funds research and development, R&D that would otherwise not happen meaning that discoveries would remain unknown as a consequence... if that corporation decides that the end point has to be a return on their investment, then that's a cost our society will have to pay. The source of the funding matters very little as long as the process is objective and transparent... and trust me when I say that any scientist publishing research in that field is going to have to withstand very heavy scrutiny from the scientific and medical communities.  I would personally love to see government put more funding into biomedical research in order to find cures to this and various other conditions... for no other reason that to see an end to the suffering that accompanies the likes of cancer, for those who develop it and for their loved ones that sit helplessly watching and waiting. To draw the conclusion that oncologists, doctors who dedicated a minimum of 10 years  into their education and training, are part of some economic conspiracy to profit on a disease is ludicrous, ignorant and ultimately insulting to their efforts to try help others.   So, I'm sorry that a 'lecture' has ensued... but for every person that spouts the whole \"\"\"\"doctors don't cure cancer because they make more money\"\"\"\", some poor sap listens and instead of getting effective early treatment, go for some completely useless alternative treatment... ultimately winding up with a cancer that is far more developed and much more difficult to treat."},{"comment_id":"10156555878200652","message":"Morgan Rampick"},{"comment_id":"10156562270330652","message":"I love them! Questions about Trump<a1><af>s mental health in relation to his behavior have floated around throughout his campaign, but in recent weeks they seem to have come to a head. It is one thing for those who oppose Trump <U+2014> such as former New York mayor Michael 266790296879 <U+2014> to make comments about his sanity. However, many medical professionals have also made statements in favor of these claims. While they<a1><af>ve stopped short of actually offering up a clinical diagnosis, psychologists seem to agree that Trump exhibits many personality characteristics that indicate narcissistic tendencies.  Narcissistic personality disorder, according to the Mayo Clinic, is a <a1><b0>mental disorder in which people have an inflated sense of their own importance, a deep need for admiration and a lack of empathy for others.<a1><b1> It seems that Trump<a1><af>s behavior fits these descriptors. The Mayo Clinic adds, though, that there is more to the disorder. <a1><b0>But behind this mask of ultraconfidence lies a fragile self-esteem that<a1><af>s vulnerable to the slightest criticism.<a1><b1>  Dan McAdams, who is a psychology professor at Northwestern University, wrote in a personality assessment that he conducted of Trump, <a1><b0>I don<a1><af>t want to argue that it<a1><af>s a clinical condition <a1><a6> but if there<a1><af>s a continuum, in terms of narcissistic personality characteristics within a relatively normal population, he<a1><af>s really way off on the extreme end.<a1><b1>  Another psychology professor, Scott Lilienfeld of Emory University, made it clear that, in his expert opinion, Donald Trump is not insane. However, Lilienfeld did note that it is important for voters to ask whether they think someone with a personality like Trump<a1><af>s <U+2014> regardless of clinical diagnosis <U+2014> is fitting for the position of Commander-in-Chief.  <a1><ae>I don<a1><af>t think he<a1><af>s out of touch with reality, I think he knows what he<a1><af>s doing, he probably doesn<a1><af>t hear voices or have delusional thinking.<a1><af>  Lilienfeld suggested voters ask themselves:  <a1><ae>Is this individual<a1><af>s narcissism so high that it might be at the upper end of the curve where it<a1><af>s no longer just healthy self-confidence, which is probably good to some degree, or is it at the point where it could really cause problems?<a1><af>  Remarks on Trump<a1><af>s narcissism have floated around for quite some time. In November 2015, Vanity Fair published a story in which several psychologists called Trump <a1><b0>Remarkably narcissistic<a1><b1> and said that he displayed <a1><b0>Textbook narcissistic personality disorder.<a1><b1>  Clinical psychologist George Simon said, <a1><b0>He<a1><af>s so classic that I<a1><af>m archiving video clips of him to use in workshops because there<a1><af>s no better example of his characteristics. Otherwise, I would have had to hire actors and write vignettes. He<a1><af>s like a dream come true.<a1><b1>  We do not have a clinical diagnosis of Trump, and we will likely never get one. As The Star points out, <a1><b0>U.S. psychiatrists are now prohibited by their professional association from publicly assessing public figures.<a1><b1>  However, there is plenty to criticize about Trump without resorting to calling him crazy, insane, or any of the other names that are tossed around by the media or were used at the Democratic National Convention.  David Perry, a disability rights journalist, told The Star, <a1><b0>the casual association of behavior we find objectionable or erratic with mental illness spreads stigma.<a1><b1>  Perry continued, backing up the point that, with or without a diagnosis, Trump is a poor choice for president.  <a1><ae>He<a1><af>s a liar, he<a1><af>s a bigot, he makes bad decisions, he<a1><af>s erratic and unpredictable.
